A jury in the New York State Supreme Court which had acquitted Frank Chanowski of the murder of Michael Bianco was told by Judge Wilmot M. Smith that its ,erdict was about the worst miscarriage of justice he had ever known. Judge Smith said Never before have I said anything to a jury about a verdict, but your verdict is about the worst miscar riage of justice I have ever known. It a disgrace to Suffolk county. You may go.

document.text: Your own will not bear inspec tion!  charged Clark, turning to Man ning with a scowl. Ill range up at the judgment seat with you! flamed Manning. Were both old enough td think about that! Joseph G. Clark jumped to his feet and, leaning across the table, shook a thin forefinger at Manning. I have been attacked enough on the point of my moral standing! he de clared, his high-pitched nasal voice quavering with an anger he had held below the explosive point during the most of his life. I can stand the at tacks of a sensational press, but when spiteful criticism follows me into my own vestry, almost in the sacred shadow of the altar itself, 1 am com pelled to protest! I wish to state to this vestry, once and for all, that my moral status is above reproach, and that my conduct has been such as to receive the commendation of my Ma ker! Because it has pleased Divine Providence to place in my hands the distribution of the grain of the fields, I rfm constantly subject to the attacks of envy and malice! It has gone so far that I, last night, received froqj Rev. Smith Boyd, a request to resign from this vestry! He paused in tri umph on that, as if he had made against Rev. Smith Boyd a charge of such ghastly infamy that the young rector must shrivel before his eyes. I have led a blameless life! I have never smoked nor drunk! I have paid every penny I ever owed and fulfilled every promise I ever n!ade. 1 have obeyed the gospel and partaken of the sacraments, and the Divine Being has rewarded me abundantly! He has Chosen me, because of my faithful stewardship, to gather the food of earth from its sources and feed it to the mouths of the hungry  and I shall not depart from my stewardship in this church, because I am here, as I am everywhere, by the will of God! Perhaps W. T. Chisholm was not shocked by this blasphemy, but the dismay of it sat on every other face, even on that of Nicholas Van Ploon, whp was compelled to dig deep to flnd his ethics. You Infernal old thief! wondered Manning, recovering from his amaze ment. Was it Divine Providence which directed you to devise the scheme whereby the railroads paid you two dollars rebate on every car of wheat you shipped, and a dollar bonus on every car of wheat your com petitors shipped? I could give youi string of sins as long as the catechism and you dare not deny one of them, because I can prove them on you! And yet you have the effrontery to say that a Divine Providence would estab lish you in your monopoly, by such scoundrelly means as you have risen to become the greatest dispenser of self-advertising charities in the world! You propose to ride into heaven on your universities and your libraries, and on the fact that you never smoked n6r drank nor swore nor gambled but when you come face to face with this horrible new god you have cre ated, a deity who would permit you to attain wealth by the vile methods you have used, you will find him with a pitchfork in his hands! I am glad that Doctor Boyd, though knowing your vindictive record, has had brav ery enough to demand your resigna tion from this vestry! I hope he re ceives it! . Joseph G. Clark had remained standing, and his head shook, as with palsy, while he listened tothe charge

document.text: you saw them, Castner? They were In front of Pegleg Johns in the .nest block- Miss Mas singale was waiting for Smith, who was just coming out of Peglegs den shaking his head. 1 put two. nnfl two together and guessed they were look ing for Stephen. If the? went there Miss Amy had her reasons., Lets try it, said Brouil lard, and he was half-way across street when Castner overtook him. There was a dance hall next door to Pegleg Johns barrel house and gam bling rooms, and, though the daylight was still strong enough to make tt electrics garishly unnecessary, the orgy was In full swing, the raucous clanging of a piano, and the shuffle and stamp of many feet drowning the monotonous cries of the sidewalk barker, who was inviting all and sundry to enter and join the dancers. Castner would have stopped to ques tion the barkerwas, in fact, trying to make himself heardwhen the sharp crash of a pistol shot dominated the clamor of the piano and the stamp ing feet. Brouillard made a quick dash for the open door of the neighboring barrel house, and Castner was so good a second that they burst in as one man. The dingy interior of Pegleg Johns, which was merely a barrel-lined vesti bule leading to the gambling rooms beyond, staged a tragedy. A handsome young giant, out of whose face sudden agony had driven the brooding pas sion of intoxication, lay, loose-flung, on the sawdust-covered floor, with Amy Massingale kneeling In stricken, tearless misery beside him. Almost within arms reach Van Bruce Cort wright, the slayer, was wrestling stub bornly with Tig Smith and the fat armed barkeeper, who were trying to disarm him, his heavy face a mask of irresponsible rage and his lips bub bling imprecations. Turn me loose. he gritted. Ill fix him so he wont give the governors snap away! Hell pipe the story of the Coronida grant off to the-papers? not if I kill him till hes too dead to bury, I guess. Castner ignored the wrestling three and dropped quickly on his knees be side Stephen Massingale, bracing the misery-stricken girl with the needed word of hope and directing her in low tones how to help him search for the wound. But Brouillard hurleid himself with an oath upon young Cortwright, and it was be, and neither the cattleman nor the fat-armed barkeeper, who wrenched the weapon out of Cortwriglits grasp and with it menaced the babbling mur derer into silence.

document.text: You Get Results Of The Times-Virginiai Appomattox Presbytery -Ministers and Elders, repre senting eighty area Presbyterian Churches, met in Farmlville on i Tuesday, January 22. for the j winter meeting of Appomattox i Presbytery. Elder E. -Bruce Har-  vey, Attorney at Law, of Altavis ta, was elected and served ably I as Moderator of the meeting. Presbytery elected its Com missioners to the 1963 meeting of the General Assembly which is scheduled -to meet In the First Presbyterian Church in Hunting- ton W. Va., beginning April 25. Commissioners elected were Ministers  James G. Thompson of Lynchburg, J. Hoge Smith, Jr. of Farmville, and William B. Gold of Altavista and Elders James R. Caskie of Lynchburg, Prof. Philip iH. Ropp of Hamp- den-Sydney, and Edward Wilson of Danville. The main address of the day wias delivered by Dr. W. C. Mc- Lauchlin, former missionary to China and Japan. Dr. McLaugh lin spoke on the Menace of Communism from his first hand experience. He divided his mess age under the cause, he stated that he believed communism to be Satan inspired and Satan con trolled ts evil is beyond hu man ingenuity. He used the term sham to describe its deliber ate deception under the pretext of doing good. Its progress is so rapid because it builds on add takes advantage of the selfish ness and the somnolence sleepiness of backward peo ples. but which are to be found so prevalent among may na tions, including our own. The curse of communism? No regard for human life un conditional atheism unmoral standaids anything is right if it helps the Communist cause, wrong if it is harmful to that cause universal suspicion un- paralled spying even among children and the closest of friends. document.text: You ask why I, a Freemason, sup port Governor Smith, a Catholic, tor the Presidency of the United States. There Is no connection between my Freemasonry, the Governors Catholic ism and my advocacy of his election as President. Freemasonry has no concern, with any mans religion other than to exact of its members belief in God and moral lives. Governor Smith Is a God-fearing man, a churchman and lives a moral life. Freemasonry has no concern with politics other than to urge its members to be loyal citizens, obdlent to the laws oftheir country. I, then, as a Freemason am bound to uphold the Constitution and the laws of my country. These for bid a religious test as a qualification for public office. It follows then that a Freemason Is disloyal to -his orders- and, betrays it who opposes Governor Smiths elec tion solely because the Governor Is a Catholic, Snd such a one also is dis loyal to our country  because he ap plies a, religious tegt as a Quallfica- tlori to r office,which, the Constitution of the United States forbids. document.text: Yesterday was the 100th a n n i versary of the establishment of a U. iS. Post Office at what is bow Appo mattox, Virginia. Information secured from Nation al Archives and the Post Office De partment, Washington, D. C., tells an interesting story of a full cen tury of mail service here. There have been 20 postmaster andor acting postmaster ap pointments in the 100 years of operation and the incumbent, E. LeRoy Smith, has served longer than any other. The name of the office has been changed several times. On February 23, 1855, a fourth class post office was established here and was call ed Nebraska, Virginia. The first postmaster was Samuel D. McDear- mon. Salary amounted to 6.01. The office operated under the name of Nebraska, Virginia until September 21, 1894, when it was changed to Appomattox. However, due to confusion with the Old Ap pomattox Court House community, the ñamé of the post office here changed on January 15, 189 to West Appomattox, Virginia. It oper ated under that name until June 27, 1906, when it took the present name of Appomattox, Virginia. The office became third class in 1909 and second class in 1987. In mid-1955 it is scheduled to become first class, due to volume of busi ness. Several years ago it became first class, but reverted to second class due to a shift in parcel post business. The following is a list of post masters and their terms Samuel D. MeDearmon, February 23, 1855 Richard H, Mavin, December 31. 1855 Robert I, Boaz, October 4, 1866 Thomas E. Walton, December 22 1867k D- Hix, April 20, 1869 Willbfo l CoIKntf April 1 , i860 Mrs. Mary J. Atwood, February 10, 1666.  Ada A. Landrum, June 26, 1866 N. H. Gregory, October 30, 1867 Miss Elizftbéth H. Dee, Jániury 21, 188 Rufus Furdum, January 1, 1873 Samuel H. Coleman, July 26, 1889 John S. Plunkett, May 9, 1898 Robert Irby, May 7, 1897 Leslie F. Ferguson, May 20, 1918 Robert Irby, April 28, 1922 Lula G. Irby, Acting Postmaster. Ap ril 21, 921 Alfred R. Harwood, Acting Poet- master, May 15, 7931 Joseph E. Dinwiddle, June 1, 1982 E. LeRoy Smith, Acting Poet- master, June 1, 1034 Regular Appointment, March 8, 1936. However, this was not the first pqst. office in what is now Appomat tox County, Tie following inform ation  supplied by the National Archives and reports of the Post Office Department Appomattox County, Virginia The records show that this office was established on April 1, 1811, under the name of Floods, Buckings ham County, Virginia, with Thomas Trent the first postmaster. It is shown that the name oi the county was changed to Prince Edward on March 22, 1837, that the name of the office was changed to Clover Hill on July 7, 1837 and that the county in which the office was lo cated was changed to Appomattox sometime between September 23, 1845 and June 30, 1849. The re cords show that the name of the office was changed to Appomattox Court House on February 3, 1859 and changed to Appomattox on July 3, 1892.  It therefore appears that the his tory of a post office at what is now without a post office but known as Old Appomattox Court House, is equally interesting. That part of the county was in Buckingham when the post office was established as Floods in 1811. Later it became a part of Prince Edward and finally Appo mattox in 1845. Shortly after the burning of the court house in 1892, the court house was rebuilt at what is now the Town of Appomattox, and final ly the post office at the historic old village was discontinued. It was of ficially Appomattox Court House, Virginia, at the time Gen. Lee sur rendered to Gen. Grant. Undocumented stories often told here relate that in the gold rush days a hundred years and more ago?- some family started out for Ne braska, got this far and liked the place so much that they decided to settle here and call this Nebraska. This newspaper has no proof of that

document.text: Yesterday morning at oclock, the home of Mr Mrs. M. C. Smith was the scene of a pretty marriage, when their daughter, Miss Frances Amelia, became the bride of Mr. Rolanc Walton Jamerson. The parlor was beautifully decorated with ferns and cut flowers. Just be fore the ceremony At Dawn ing was rendered on the violin by Hon. J. R. Horseley, with piano accompaniment by Mrs. C W. Smith. The couple enterec the parlor to the strains of Lohengrins Wedding March, and stood under an arch of sweet peas, where they were met by Rev. D. G. Trent, the pastor of the bride, who officiated in a very impressive manner, the ring ceremony being used, dur ing which O Promise Me was played softly on the Piano. The bride was attired in a beautiful costume of New Blue Chiffon Crepe, with accessories to match, and carried an arm bouquet of Butterfly Roses and was at tended by Miss Emily Harvey Immediately after the ceremony, the happy couple left for an auto tour through the Valley of Va., and will visit Hagerstown and Baltimore, Md., Washington, D. C., Richmond, Va., and other points of interest before return ing. They will be at home here after July 4th. The bride, who is a steno grapher employed in the Clerks 05ce, is one of the popular girls of our town, takes an active interest in church, community, and social affairs, and has many friends here. The groom is a prosperous young business man, and has been a valued employee of the Ould-Lawson Hardware Co., for the past several years. Our best wishes go with this young couple.

document.text: Yesterday a west bound freight train put out a fire which burned over about 1000 acres of land on the north side of the road between this point and Evergreen. A barn was burned on the farm cf Mrs. S. H. Kelley. Several small houses were also burned and it is said one cow  perished in the flames. Tbe same engine set fire to a shed at this place in the Smith block, and but for the timely discovery v. ould have resulted in a serious conflagration.

document.text: yesrs ago, as I know now. Torrence graduated from Ap pomattox High School. During high school years he was active of SCA, a member of the Beta Club, vice president  Mi im cnapoer, and winner in the FFA state and southern region farm mechanics competi tion. At VtPI he has continued his extra - curricular activities. He is a member of ODK, Alpha Zeta, the collegiate FFA chapter, cadet captain, a member of Scabbard and Blade, and a distinguished military student. Torrence was commissioned this June and will spend two years in service. Then he plans to take a masters degree in agriculture and teach vocational agriculture in Virginia. Winner of Tnree Scholarships He received three schoarships during this student days at VPI. These include the Smith -Douglas scholarship, a state teachers scholarship, and the Newman scholarship.

document.text: Yes, I ship a good many, said Evans. Why do you ask? T v e just had all my white Leg horns stolenforty of them. Every one round here is losing chickens. Now those chickens have to be mar keted somewhereand not around here. Its fifty miles to the city, which is the safest place to m arket them. If I stole chickens, Id freight them down, dressed and packed in barrels. So I thought if anybody round here was doing the thieving and the thieves, whoever they are, take the local paper, and certainly do know this part of the county as well as their hand  I m ight get some hint from your shipments. Thats a first rate idea, said the young man. But I dont remember any special shipper of dressed poul try in barrels. The W alter boys pack that way, but I guess were not sus pecting them! Mrs. Dixon sends a barrel now and then. So do the peo ple on the Lawrence farm th ats been an experimental poultry farm for the last year. I hear they report they lost badly through a raid by the thieves two months ago. The Elliotts, over at Orwell, send dressed poultry, too, but never very much. It doesnt seem------- .No, it doesnt, said Dorothy, looking perplexed. But these chick ens have got to get to market, Frank, somehow. Ive started to hunt this county over till I find whats become of them. I guess Id better drive to the other stations up and down the road. Theyd be likely to choose a stupid agent to ship through, so I dnt wonder they keep away from here. Then she flushed a t having paid Frank a compliment, and Frank flushed, too, with pleasure, for he knew that his pretty schoolmate never said things unless she meant them. It p u t him on his mettle. But see here, Dorothy, why do you have to drive up and down the road? W hats the m atter with my telegraphing instead? Come in and sit down, and I ll get you all the in formation you want in half an hour. So Dorothy sat and listened to the clicking w.ires, and took some brief notes on a telegraph pad that Frank pushed over to her across the table. Wagner, at Dorrance station, says that the Lawrence farm sends a bar rel now and then and a crate occa sionally. The Widow Ransom is the heaviest shipper sends both crates and barrels. Jones, at Pond station, says Hank Janeway ships a barrel sometimes so does the Lawrence farm. The Browns send a crate now and then white Leghorns and Ply mouth Rocks. Collins, at Pelham Junction, says that Mrs. Robinson ships more than anybody else, but Jim Henry sends a barrel or a crate now and then, and so does the Law rence peoplePlymouth Rocks, most ly. King, at Bellevue station, says everybody sends in crates, except a barrel now and then from the Law rence people and Sally W alker. Frank leaned back and whistled softly. Dorothy smiled and pushed the telegraph pad under his eyes. Five underlinings marked the name Lawrence repeated in each of the five reports from Milby, Dorrance, Pond, Pelham and Bellevue. You clever girl! said Frank. Youve got hold of the right end. No honest poultry farm ever shipped that much to the city, and through five different stations in small lots. But supposing its so, how are we go ing to prove it? The man doesnt live who can identify an ordinary white Leghorn hen or Plymouth Rock pul let. But the girl does! cried Dorothy, triumphantly. Since day before yesterday I can pick out any one of my forty Leghorns with absolute cer tainty, Frank. I I dipped their legs, every one of them, in a fast black that wont come off, so that I could know them again if they were stolen. Frank Evans lay back in his chair and laughed delightedly. Dorothy, you always were at the head of the class, he said, heartily. But what are you going to do now? Im going to the Lawrence farm , said Dorothy, unfastening the hitch ing strap. You mustnt do that. They might do you an injury. W ait till I can get a constable and a search warrant. You m ustnt go alone, Dorothy. , I wont have it. I dont mind a search w arrant, said Dorothy, with composure. That is what I brought this for. She pulled out the mysterious box, and disclosed various brightly labeled bottles and packages. I am Miss Jane Smith, Frank, agent for these poultry remedies, which I am driv ing about the county introducing among intelligent poultry farmers. I shall get into the Lawrence chicken yards, and come away again without any trouble, thank you. But I should like the constable to be at the end of the lane, ready to come in a little later. Ill get Dick Williams to tend the station, said Frank, and drive over with you p u t the constables and

Smith has either done or supervised most, if not all, of the site preparation and tree planting on private land in this county since he began working for the Division of Forestry, commented Bowman. In the past 24 years. Smith has located contractors to plant trees, to push firelines, to prescribe burn cut l over woodland, to hand release pine and he has performed countless other services, added Bow man. Born and reared on a farm, a lover of the out of doors, Smith plans to spend more time gardening, an activity which, is already one of his favorite hobbies. I might even try fishing, laughed Smith, if I can learn how to be a good fisherman. Smith is married to the former Bessie Carter of Buckingham and they háve one daughter, Diane Smith Kester- ton of Lynchburg. The Smiths are members of Hollywood Baptist Church. The people who have worked with David and all of the people of Appomattox County willsurely miss his help in protecting and managing the woodlands of Appomattox County, concluded Bowman.
